body:
(2 Samuel 24:1) Again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.”

(1 Chronicles 21:1) Satan rose up against Israel and incited David to take a census of Israel.

They are both the same story as David takes a census of his people. But who commands David to take a census is obviously very different.

I think (Isaiah 45:6-7) is an interesting depiction of LORD as he describes himself saying:

"That they may know from the rising of the sun, and from the west, that there is none beside me. I am the LORD, and there is none else. I form the light, and create darkness: I make peace, and create evil: I the LORD do all these things."

My question is were the ancient Israelites often deceived or confused about who exactly they worshipped? Or are these passages showing the evolving theology of the ancient Israelites?

"Show no pity: life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot." (Deuteronomy 19:21)

In the Law Moses commanded us to stone such women. Now what do you say?” Jesus replied, “Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her.” Jesus said to the woman, “Neither do I condemn you. Go now and leave your life of sin.” (John 8:3-5, 11)
"If a man commits adultery with another man’s wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress are to be put to death." (Leviticus 20:10)

"But I tell you, do not swear an oath at all… all you need to say is simply ‘Yes’ or ‘No’; anything beyond this comes from the evil one." (Matthew 5:34, 37)

"Then Jesus said to him, “Get up! Pick up your mat and walk.” At once the man was cured; he picked up his mat and walked. The understanding is that God created the circumstances which would have made most people relent, but these circumstances kept stacking up, and Pharaoah, who is said to be *hardening his own heart during the first disasters*, has had his heart hardened even further through doubling down with each further event. 

Thus, God is not literally suspending Pharaoh's free will and hardening his heart; he is giving him the rope to hang himself with, by providing even more circumstances for him to turn back. 

This is how Fr. Mitch Pacwa once explained this phenomenon. He is a Catholic priest famous for his work on EWTN.

body:
>My question is were the ancient Israelites often deceived or confused about who exactly they worshipped? Or are these passages showing the evolving theology of the ancient Israelites?

They knew the difference between God and Satan, and they knew that God was right to worship. Of course, some miscreants also worshiped other deities *in the high places.* This is a continuous theme. 

The evolving relationship with God comes in just a few stages, really, with the stage before Moses brings them out of Israel; the stage after Moses; and then, the Messiah, Jesus Christ coming. I am no expert on this and I am sure that experts *would certainly divide this further,* talking about how the relationship with God perhaps changed during the downfall that led to the Babylonian Captivity, the relationship after the Babylonian captivity, etc., but I think that we do not lose too much meaning by generalizing more broadly as we are Christians whose chief focus should be on Christ.

I also think it is the case that what you cited above does not necessarily match up with your questions. I do not see a contradiction.

body:
> My question is were the ancient Israelites often deceived or confused about who exactly they worshipped? 

I think the answer is no. Are you thinking that God is the same as Satan, and these are getting mixed up?

> Or are these passages showing the evolving theology of the ancient Israelites?

I'm not sure it's this either.

A distinction has been made between natural and moral evil; moral evil is sin, it is freely chosen and unnecessary, creating problems in the world, like committing an assault and battery - unprovoked. God commits no moral evil, while Satan has committed moral evil. Natural evil might be like a hurricane that comes through and causes loss of life. God permits this to happen (but I think this only came about as a punishment for sin or moral evil).
